basics.name: Onyekachi Osisiogu
basics.label: Scientist
basics.summary: Data scientist and computational mathematician with a Ph.D. in Computational Mathematics.

work.name: Illinois Institute of Technology
work.summary: At Illinois Institute of Technology, I served as a Senior Research Associate and Visiting Assistant Professor, focusing on algorithm efficiency and Information-Based Complexity. I collaborated on innovative projects and delivered engaging lectures in undergraduate calculus courses.

work.name: Johann Radon Institute for Computational and Applied Mathematics (RICAM)
work.summary: At RICAM, I collaborated with an international research team to develop efficient quasi-Monte Carlo algorithms, resulting in four journal publications. I optimized data exchange within the team, boosting research productivity.

volunteer.summary: As an AI/Data Science Trainer, I designed a comprehensive curriculum for data science and AI tracks, ensuring alignment with industry best practices. I created hands-on learning materials, including case studies and coding exercises.
highlights: Developed a cutting-edge curriculum for data science and AI
Created hands-on learning materials and real-world datasets
Ensured alignment with industry best practices and emerging trends

certificates.name: Python for Data Science, AI & Development

publications.name: On a reduced component-by-component digit-by-digit construction of lattice point sets
publications.summary: This paper introduces an efficient reduced fast component-by-component digit-by-digit (CBC-DBD) algorithm for constructing lattice point sets in quasi-Monte Carlo integration. The method is particularly effective for weighted Korobov classes with rapidly decaying weights, offering computational efficiency independent of problem dimension under certain conditions. The algorithm achieves near-optimal convergence order and demonstrates significant speed improvements over previous methods.

publications.name: Construction of good polynomial lattice rules in weighted Walsh spaces by an alternative component-by-component construction
publications.summary: This research presents an alternative method for constructing good polynomial lattice rules in weighted Walsh spaces, enhancing computational efficiency in numerical simulations.

publications.name: Component-by-component digit-by-digit construction of good polynomial lattice rules in weighted Walsh spaces
publications.summary: This paper introduces a novel component-by-component digit-by-digit construction method for polynomial lattice rules, advancing the field of constructive approximation in weighted Walsh spaces.

publications.name: Digit-by-digit and component-by-component constructions of lattice rules for periodic functions with unknown smoothness
publications.summary: This research develops new construction methods for lattice rules applicable to periodic functions with unknown smoothness, contributing to the study of computational complexity.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
